comments.value:
General Information

This is a replication project being completed by an undergraduate Experimental Psychology course at Yeshiva University. A total of 18 undergraduate students and 3 graduate student instructors are contributing to the project, in addition to the PI (Lisa Chalik).

Abstract (from De Neys et al.)

Influential work on human thinking suggests that our judgment is often biased because we minimize cognitive effort and intuitively substitute hard questions by easier ones. A key question is whether or not people realize that they are doing this and notice their mistake. Here, we test this claim with one of the most publicized examples of the substitution bias, the bat-and-ball problem. We designed an isomorphic control version in which reasoners experience no intuitive pull to substitute. Results show that people are less confident in their substituted, erroneous bat-and-ball answer than in their answer on the control version that does not give rise to the substitution. Contrary to popular belief, this basic finding indicates that biased reasoners are not completely oblivious to the substitution and sense that their answer is questionable. This calls into question the characterization of the human reasoner as a happy fool who blindly answers erroneous questions without realizing it.

Planned Methods

This will be an exact replication of the original study. Participants will complete the replication online, through Qualtrics. We will collect a minimum N of 100 participants. These participants will be recruited through word-of-mouth, and will likely consist mostly of friends and family of the students conducting the project.

For exploratory purposes, we have also added some demographic questions at the end of the procedure.

attributes.title: Turtles, Task Ninjas, and Time-Wasters
attributes.description: Standard approaches for identifying task completion strategies, such as precrastination and procrastination, reduce behavior to single markers that oversimplify the process of task completion. To illustrate this point, we consider three task completion strategies and introduce a new method to identify their use. This approach was tested using a historical dataset (N = 8,655) of the available electronic records of research participation at our institution. The approach out-performed standard diagnostic approaches and yielded an interesting finding: several strategies were associated with negative outcomes. Specifically, procrastinators and precrastinators both struggled to finish tasks on time. Together, these findings underscore the importance of using holistic approaches to determine the relationship between task characteristics, individual differences, and task completion.

summary.value: This registration contains the data files for our Psychological Science publication of the same name. It also contains a peer-reviewed R-markdown document that details our primary analysis and out-of-sample validations.

registration_responses.summary: This registration contains the data files for our Psychological Science publication of the same name. It also contains a peer-reviewed R-markdown document that details our primary analysis and out-of-sample validations.

q3.value:
This project investigates how people think about the temporal relation between two time intervals. There are logical systems such as Allen's Interval Calculus that break down the relations into a set of mutually exclusive categories. The subset of relations we focus on in the current experiment are: 

STARTS - 2 events starting simultaneously and ending asynchronously
FINISHES - 2 events starting asynchronously and ending simultaneously
DURING - 2 events starting asynchronously and ending asynchronously
EQUALS - 2 events starting simultaneously and ending simultaneously

The initial analysis of generated descriptions from an earlier experiment (DT1) suggest that descriptions rarely are complete and unambiguous. By contrasting the acceptability of incomplete descriptions for intervals matching the above relations, the experiment is designed to show whether there is a bias in preferences for descriptions relations by either start times only or end times only, by the underlying temporal relation, and whether these factors interact. 

The current experiment builds on previous experiments (DT2-DT4) by using a visual diagram to provide event durations and relations to the participant.  This is designed to allay concerns that the premises of the earlier experiments always used the word 'started' before the word 'ended'. The diagram visually conveys when events start and end without requiring the use of these words that are in the response options.

q4.value:
Replicating the pattern from the DT2 results:
1. There will be a bias toward choosing the description relating start times when the underlying Allen relation is During, Equals, or Finishes.
2. There will be a bias toward choosing the description relating end times when the underlying Allen relation is Starts.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The experimental task is a 2 alternative forced choice between 2 partial descriptions across 16 problems, 4 of each temporal relation type, the same underlying structure as DT2. The events are presented as labeled rectangles above and below a timeline. The timeline was fixed at 8 hours long with the anchor times randomly assigned. The events could be 1 to 8 hours in duration and could start 0 to 7 hours after the early time anchor. For more clarity on the visual design, see the attached image for an example problem given in the instructions.

The temporal information is presented initially then the question and possible responses appear after a 2 second delay. The response options are presented on buttons that the participant clicks to indicate their response. The order of descriptions (started first or ended first) is randomized by problem. Both descriptions are always logically accurate. The experiment ends with three debriefing questions: one asking how the participant approached deciding between the descriptions, another asking if the diagrams were understandable, and one open-ended.

q9.value: A set of  32 events, 24 unique labels with 8 randomly selected repeats, were randomly assigned to the 16 problems with the restriction of not having any two labels paired together in a problem more than once. The relative times were randomly generated within an 8 hour window to fit the requirements for each Allen relation (during, equals, starts, finishes).  The timeline's early anchor was 8 hours before the late anchor and were restricted to be between 1am to 11pm. The colors of the rectangles were randomly assigned among 4 options. The placement of the events above vs. below the timeline were randomized and, finally, the display order of the problems was randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The data will be collected through Amazon Mechanical Turk by a separate research firm, Knexus Research Corporation. They will handle payment and recruitment. Eligibility for the study includes native English speakers in the US who are above 18 years of age. The study will last approximately 10 minutes, and participants will be paid $1.50 for their participation.

q14.value: The key results in DT2 were significant with a p-value well below 0.01 with 50 participants and because this is a replication with a 3rd option, 50 participants should suffice.

question.value: The underlying Allen relation of each problem scenario.
Preference between: (1) a description of the relation between the two event start times, (2) a description of the relation between the two event end times.

Our analysis will consist of testing the effect of relation (equals, starts, finishes, during) on preference.  We will compare the average portion of 'started' responses by participant to chance with Wilcoxon tests.  Then, using the 'started' response rate as the dependent variable, we will conduct a non-parametric within-subject Friedman test of the relation factor, with posthoc pair-wise comparisons.

q21.value: The alpha level is set at p < 0.05 with a Šidák-Holm correction for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded for nonsensical debriefing responses (often indicating a bot instead of a human participant), for indicating they did not take the experiment seriously, for not following instructions, or for response patterns such as always selecting the first response.

q23.value: We will only include participants who completed all 16 problems.  We do record incomplete sessions that could be looked at in an exploratory manner.

q24.value: We will use a linear mixed effect regression model with estimated marginal means for the post-hoc contrasts.  The regression model will have the fixed effect of relation as well random factors for participant (intercept and random slopes by relation).  We will explore whether randomized variables as well as demographic variables affect any differences by Allen relation observed.

registration_responses.q19.question: Systematic review

q1.value: The role of prior knowledge in adults’ word learning from spoken stories

q2.value: Emma James, M. Gareth Gaskell, Lisa Henderson

q3.value:
We have previously shown that phonological neighbours facilitate word learning in children and adults, but that this influence of prior knowledge can change across consolidation (James, Gaskell, & Henderson, 2019). In these experiments, the benefit of prior knowledge was apparent immediately—perhaps facilitated by use of explicit word learning strategies—but weakened over consolidation. In the present study, we ask whether this same pattern holds when novel words are encountered incidentally when listening to stories. 

Two experiments have already been completed to address this question (see https://osf.io/stx6q/). An experiment with children showed that children were not influenced by word neighbours when recalling novel words learned from stories, as measured by a stem completion task. In a form recognition task, they showed poorer performance for novel words that had phonological neighbours, suggesting that prior knowledge even interfered with new learning. In an experiment with adults however, we saw no such interference, and adults continued to benefit from phonological neighbours in recalling the pseudowords as they had done in explicit learning tasks.

However, differences in the experimental set-up make it challenging to interpret the differences between children and adults. First, adults were presented with the written stories to read along with the spoken stories, whereas children were not exposed to any orthography. This additional support enabled participants to revisit the novel words during the story, against the intended implicit nature of learning. Second, children sat separate 2-AFC recognition tasks to assess knowledge of the word-form and picture-form mapping independently, and the word-form recognition task was sensitive to neighbor effects. However, performance cannot be directly compared with adults because adults sat a combined 4-AFC version assessing form and picture knowledge simultaneously. Third, children provided spoken word responses, whereas adults provided typed responses. The present aim is to ameliorate these differences in a second adult study, using identical encoding and test formats to the original child experiment. 

Our primary research questions are as follows: 
1) Do adults show benefits from offline consolidation after learning novel words from spoken stories? 
2) Do adults show benefits of local prior knowledge (i.e., from word neighbours) when learning novel words from spoken stories?
3) Is the time course of local prior knowledge benefits different when adults learn novel words from spoken stories, compared to previous studies using explicit teaching paradigms (James et al., 2019)? 
4) Are benefits of local prior knowledge related to adults’ existing expressive vocabulary knowledge?

q4.value:
1) Memory for the novel words will be different after opportunities for consolidation at the day and week follow-up tests compared to when tested immediately after learning. In line with previous studies (James et al., 2019; Henderson et al., 2015), we predict that recall in the stem completion task will improve at later test points. 

2) Memory for the novel words will be affected by their number of phonological neighbours. For the stem completion task, we predict that words with one/more neighbours will be better recalled than words without neighbours. We also test this hypothesis in the recognition tasks, although do not predict a specific direction given our previous experiments have demonstrated that both interference and facilitation are plausible. 

3) The influence of word neighbours on memory for the novel words will change after opportunities for consolidation. If the same pattern holds as with explicit teaching paradigms, we would expect an early benefit of word neighbours to weaken after consolidation. However, if initial prior knowledge connections are weaker under storybook learning conditions, we may see that the influence of neighbours instead becomes strengthened with consolidation. This alternative would manifest as a delayed benefit for word neighbours at the day or week follow-up tests, and may be most prominent for words with only one neighbour due to their more limited prior knowledge connections. 

4) Expressive vocabulary scores will be positively associated with overall memory performance for the novel words. In line with previous findings, we anticipate that the association between vocabulary and memory performance will be strongest for novel words with only one phonological neighbour.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The experiment uses a within-subjects design, with each participant learning words from three word neighbour conditions (none, one, many) and completing memory tests at three time points (immediately, +1 day, +1 week). Three counterbalancing conditions have been created such that the novel concepts in the story are associated with a word from each neighbour condition across participants. 

Vocabulary ability is a between-subjects measure.

q9.value:
Participants are randomly assigned to a counterbalancing condition via the Gorilla experiment platform, ensuring a balanced number of participants in each condition overall. 

All recall and recognition tests will have the items presented in a randomized order.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited using Prolific Academic, and will complete the experimental tasks online via the Gorilla experiment platform. All will be native monolingual British English-speaking adults, without any reading or language disorders. All must have normal or corrected-to-normal hearing and vision. In line with Prolific's recommendations for longitudinal studies, we will restrict recruitment to individuals who have taken part in at least 10 studies on the platform with a minimum 95% approval rate.

They will receive £5 payment for completion of the study, with a £1 bonus for completing the sessions at a similar time each time (within a 4-hour window).

q13.value: We will test 129 participants (acceptable range 124-134), allowing 43 in each of the three counterbalancing conditions. Each participant will be exposed to 15 words in the story, five from each of the word neighbour conditions (none, one, many).

q14.value: This sample will produce a similar number of observations for analysis to the previous adult study it is based on. It also exceeds recommendations by Brysbaert & Stevens (2018) to include at least 1600 observations per cell of the design.

q15.value: We will allow an acceptable n of 124-134 participants. This will help to ensure that we can replace ineligible participants efficiently with room for study drop-out, avoiding the need to run small numbers of additional participants for many subsequent weeks to reach a precise n.

question.value:
Number of phonological neighbours of words learned: none, one, many
Time of test: immediate, +1 day, +1 week

Stem completion: participants will see and hear the first consonant and vowel, and must type the novel word. Participants will be encouraged to attempt a partial answer even if they are not confident in the whole word. Responses will be scored as accurate (1 vs. 0) if they read as phonologically correct.

Form Recognition task: participants will be presented with each of the pseudowords alongside a phonological foil. They must choose which of the two words they heard in the story. Responses will be scored for accuracy (1 vs. 0).

Picture-form recognition task: participants will be presented with each of the novel concepts (illustrations), and must choose which of two presented pseudowords is the correct match. Responses will be scored for accuracy (1 vs. 0).

Vocabulary ability: participants will provide typed definitions to 13 words. Each item is scored 0, 1, or 2, providing a maximum score of 26.

For each task (stem completion, form recognition, form-picture recognition), a mixed effects binomial regression model will be fitted with fixed effects of time, neighbour condition, vocabulary score and all interactions: time*neighbour condition, time*vocabulary, vocabulary*neighbour condition, and time*vocabulary*neighbour condition. Where possible, interactions that do not enhance the fit of the model (p >.2) will be pruned to enable a more parsimonious model with better specified random effects. We will then adopt a forwards best path approach to building the random effects structure (Barr et al., 2013), incorporating only those random effects justified by the data under a liberal threshold (p <.2).

q20.value:
Vocabulary ability will be scaled and centered for analysis. 

Categorical predictors will be deviance coded such that the coefficients provided are interpretable with regards to the overall mean. Time will be coded to contrast the words before and after opportunities for consolidation (T1 vs. T2&T3), and then continued change between the day and week follow-up tests (T2 vs. T3). Word neighbour contrasts will compare performance for words without and with neighbours (none vs. one+many), and the difference between the one and many neighbour conditions (one vs. many).

q21.value: We will use the standard p-value criteria of p<.05 for determining whether the independent variables are significant predictors of performance.

q22.value:
We anticipate low performance in this study, but set criteria to exclude (and replace) participants who do not engage with the tasks (given that the tasks are completed remotely, via online testing).  

We will exclude data from participants who:
1) Disclose cheating at the end of the experiment (e.g., writing the words down).
2) Show no evidence of learning, as demonstrated by failure to recall a novel word in the stem completion task across all three tests, as well as a mean recognition score at/above chance (≤.5; averaged across the two tests and all three time points).
3) Have an expressive vocabulary score <10.

Participants who are missing stem completion recordings (for 2/more sessions) will also be replaced.

q23.value: We do not anticipate full sessions of missing data, as participants not completing the three sessions will be replaced. However, recording issues could lead to missing data in the stem completion dataset. registration_responses.q1: The role of prior knowledge in adults’ word learning from spoken stories
registration_responses.q3:
We have previously shown that phonological neighbours facilitate word learning in children and adults, but that this influence of prior knowledge can change across consolidation (James, Gaskell, & Henderson, 2019). In these experiments, the benefit of prior knowledge was apparent immediately—perhaps facilitated by use of explicit word learning strategies—but weakened over consolidation. In the present study, we ask whether this same pattern holds when novel words are encountered incidentally when listening to stories. 

Two experiments have already been completed to address this question (see https://osf.io/stx6q/). An experiment with children showed that children were not influenced by word neighbours when recalling novel words learned from stories, as measured by a stem completion task. In a form recognition task, they showed poorer performance for novel words that had phonological neighbours, suggesting that prior knowledge even interfered with new learning. In an experiment with adults however, we saw no such interference, and adults continued to benefit from phonological neighbours in recalling the pseudowords as they had done in explicit learning tasks.

However, differences in the experimental set-up make it challenging to interpret the differences between children and adults. First, adults were presented with the written stories to read along with the spoken stories, whereas children were not exposed to any orthography. This additional support enabled participants to revisit the novel words during the story, against the intended implicit nature of learning. Second, children sat separate 2-AFC recognition tasks to assess knowledge of the word-form and picture-form mapping independently, and the word-form recognition task was sensitive to neighbor effects. However, performance cannot be directly compared with adults because adults sat a combined 4-AFC version assessing form and picture knowledge simultaneously. Third, children provided spoken word responses, whereas adults provided typed responses. The present aim is to ameliorate these differences in a second adult study, using identical encoding and test formats to the original child experiment. 

Our primary research questions are as follows: 
1) Do adults show benefits from offline consolidation after learning novel words from spoken stories? 
2) Do adults show benefits of local prior knowledge (i.e., from word neighbours) when learning novel words from spoken stories?
3) Is the time course of local prior knowledge benefits different when adults learn novel words from spoken stories, compared to previous studies using explicit teaching paradigms (James et al., 2019)? 
4) Are benefits of local prior knowledge related to adults’ existing expressive vocabulary knowledge?
registration_responses.q4:
1) Memory for the novel words will be different after opportunities for consolidation at the day and week follow-up tests compared to when tested immediately after learning. In line with previous studies (James et al., 2019; Henderson et al., 2015), we predict that recall in the stem completion task will improve at later test points. 

2) Memory for the novel words will be affected by their number of phonological neighbours. For the stem completion task, we predict that words with one/more neighbours will be better recalled than words without neighbours. We also test this hypothesis in the recognition tasks, although do not predict a specific direction given our previous experiments have demonstrated that both interference and facilitation are plausible. 

3) The influence of word neighbours on memory for the novel words will change after opportunities for consolidation. If the same pattern holds as with explicit teaching paradigms, we would expect an early benefit of word neighbours to weaken after consolidation. However, if initial prior knowledge connections are weaker under storybook learning conditions, we may see that the influence of neighbours instead becomes strengthened with consolidation. This alternative would manifest as a delayed benefit for word neighbours at the day or week follow-up tests, and may be most prominent for words with only one neighbour due to their more limited prior knowledge connections. 

4) Expressive vocabulary scores will be positively associated with overall memory performance for the novel words. In line with previous findings, we anticipate that the association between vocabulary and memory performance will be strongest for novel words with only one phonological neighbour.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9:
Participants are randomly assigned to a counterbalancing condition via the Gorilla experiment platform, ensuring a balanced number of participants in each condition overall. 

All recall and recognition tests will have the items presented in a randomized order.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We will test 129 participants (acceptable range 124-134), allowing 43 in each of the three counterbalancing conditions. Each participant will be exposed to 15 words in the story, five from each of the word neighbour conditions (none, one, many).
registration_responses.q14: This sample will produce a similar number of observations for analysis to the previous adult study it is based on. It also exceeds recommendations by Brysbaert & Stevens (2018) to include at least 1600 observations per cell of the design.
registration_responses.q15: We will allow an acceptable n of 124-134 participants. This will help to ensure that we can replace ineligible participants efficiently with room for study drop-out, avoiding the need to run small numbers of additional participants for many subsequent weeks to reach a precise n.
registration_responses.q20:
Vocabulary ability will be scaled and centered for analysis. 

Categorical predictors will be deviance coded such that the coefficients provided are interpretable with regards to the overall mean. Time will be coded to contrast the words before and after opportunities for consolidation (T1 vs. T2&T3), and then continued change between the day and week follow-up tests (T2 vs. T3). Word neighbour contrasts will compare performance for words without and with neighbours (none vs. one+many), and the difference between the one and many neighbour conditions (one vs. many).
registration_responses.q21: We will use the standard p-value criteria of p<.05 for determining whether the independent variables are significant predictors of performance.
registration_responses.q22:
We anticipate low performance in this study, but set criteria to exclude (and replace) participants who do not engage with the tasks (given that the tasks are completed remotely, via online testing).  

We will exclude data from participants who:
1) Disclose cheating at the end of the experiment (e.g., writing the words down).
2) Show no evidence of learning, as demonstrated by failure to recall a novel word in the stem completion task across all three tests, as well as a mean recognition score at/above chance (≤.5; averaged across the two tests and all three time points).
3) Have an expressive vocabulary score <10.

Participants who are missing stem completion recordings (for 2/more sessions) will also be replaced.
registration_responses.q23: We do not anticipate full sessions of missing data, as participants not completing the three sessions will be replaced. However, recording issues could lead to missing data in the stem completion dataset. We will include participants who are missing stem completion data for up to one of the three sessions (e.g., if their recordings are of too low quality to score, or if they have contacted us with technical issues). Occasional corrupt/unintelligible item recordings will be excluded from the model as missing data.
registration_responses.q8.question:
The experiment uses a within-subjects design, with each participant learning words from three word neighbour conditions (none, one, many) and completing memory tests at three time points (immediately, +1 day, +1 week). Three counterbalancing conditions have been created such that the novel concepts in the story are associated with a word from each neighbour condition across participants. 

Vocabulary ability is a between-subjects measure.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited using Prolific Academic, and will complete the experimental tasks online via the Gorilla experiment platform. All will be native monolingual British English-speaking adults, without any reading or language disorders. All must have normal or corrected-to-normal hearing and vision. In line with Prolific's recommendations for longitudinal studies, we will restrict recruitment to individuals who have taken part in at least 10 studies on the platform with a minimum 95% approval rate.

They will receive £5 payment for completion of the study, with a £1 bonus for completing the sessions at a similar time each time (within a 4-hour window).
registration_responses.q16.question:
Number of phonological neighbours of words learned: none, one, many
Time of test: immediate, +1 day, +1 week
registration_responses.q17.question:
Stem completion: participants will see and hear the first consonant and vowel, and must type the novel word. Participants will be encouraged to attempt a partial answer even if they are not confident in the whole word. Responses will be scored as accurate (1 vs. 0) if they read as phonologically correct.

Form Recognition task: participants will be presented with each of the pseudowords alongside a phonological foil. They must choose which of the two words they heard in the story. Responses will be scored for accuracy (1 vs. 0).

Picture-form recognition task: participants will be presented with each of the novel concepts (illustrations), and must choose which of two presented pseudowords is the correct match. Responses will be scored for accuracy (1 vs. 0).

Vocabulary ability: participants will provide typed definitions to 13 words. Each item is scored 0, 1, or 2, providing a maximum score of 26.
registration_responses.q19.question: For each task (stem completion, form recognition, form-picture recognition), a mixed effects binomial regression model will be fitted with fixed effects of time, neighbour condition, vocabulary score and all interactions: time*neighbour condition, time*vocabulary, vocabulary*neighbour condition, and time*vocabulary*neighbour condition. Where possible, interactions that do not enhance the fit of the model (p >.2) will be pruned to enable a more parsimonious model with better specified random effects. We will then adopt a forwards best path approach to building the random effects structure (Barr et al., 2013), incorporating only those random effects justified by the data under a liberal threshold (p <.2).

question.value:

question.value:
Number of phonological neighbours of words learned: none, one, many
Time of test: immediate, +1 day, +1 week

Stem completion: participants will see and hear the first consonant and vowel, and must type the novel word. Participants will be encouraged to attempt a partial answer even if they are not confident in the whole word. Responses will be scored as accurate (1 vs. 0) if they read as phonologically correct.

Form Recognition task: participants will be presented with each of the pseudowords alongside a phonological foil. They must choose which of the two words they heard in the story. Responses will be scored for accuracy (1 vs. 0).

Picture-form recognition task: participants will be presented with each of the novel concepts (illustrations), and must choose which of two presented pseudowords is the correct match. Responses will be scored for accuracy (1 vs. 0).

Vocabulary ability: participants will provide typed definitions to 13 words. Each item is scored 0, 1, or 2, providing a maximum score of 26.

For each task (stem completion, form recognition, form-picture recognition), a mixed effects binomial regression model will be fitted with fixed effects of time, neighbour condition, vocabulary score and all interactions: time*neighbour condition, time*vocabulary, vocabulary*neighbour condition, and time*vocabulary*neighbour condition. Where possible, interactions that do not enhance the fit of the model (p >.2) will be pruned to enable a more parsimonious model with better specified random effects. We will then adopt a forwards best path approach to building the random effects structure (Barr et al., 2013), incorporating only those random effects justified by the data under a liberal threshold (p <.2).

q20.value:
Vocabulary ability will be scaled and centered for analysis. 

Categorical predictors will be deviance coded such that the coefficients provided are interpretable with regards to the overall mean. Time will be coded to contrast the words before and after opportunities for consolidation (T1 vs. T2&T3), and then continued change between the day and week follow-up tests (T2 vs. T3). Word neighbour contrasts will compare performance for words without and with neighbours (none vs. one+many), and the difference between the one and many neighbour conditions (one vs. many).

q21.value: We will use the standard p-value criteria of p<.05 for determining whether the independent variables are significant predictors of performance.

q22.value:
We anticipate low performance in this study, but set criteria to exclude (and replace) participants who do not engage with the tasks (given that the tasks are completed remotely, via online testing).  

We will exclude data from participants who:
1) Disclose cheating at the end of the experiment (e.g., writing the words down).
2) Show no evidence of learning, as demonstrated by failure to recall a novel word in the stem completion task across all three tests, as well as a mean recognition score at/above chance (≤.5; averaged across the two tests and all three time points).
3) Have an expressive vocabulary score <10.

Participants who are missing stem completion recordings (for 2/more sessions) will also be replaced.

q23.value: We do not anticipate full sessions of missing data, as participants not completing the three sessions will be replaced. However, recording issues could lead to missing data in the stem completion dataset. We will include participants who are missing stem completion data for up to one of the three sessions (e.g., if their recordings are of too low quality to score, or if they have contacted us with technical issues). Occasional corrupt/unintelligible item recordings will be excluded from the model as missing data.

registration_responses.q1: The role of prior knowledge in adults’ word learning from spoken stories
registration_responses.q3:
We have previously shown that phonological neighbours facilitate word learning in children and adults, but that this influence of prior knowledge can change across consolidation (James, Gaskell, & Henderson, 2019). In these experiments, the benefit of prior knowledge was apparent immediately—perhaps facilitated by use of explicit word learning strategies—but weakened over consolidation. In the present study, we ask whether this same pattern holds when novel words are encountered incidentally when listening to stories. 

Two experiments have already been completed to address this question (see https://osf.io/stx6q/). An experiment with children showed that children were not influenced by word neighbours when recalling novel words learned from stories, as measured by a stem completion task. In a form recognition task, they showed poorer performance for novel words that had phonological neighbours, suggesting that prior knowledge even interfered with new learning. In an experiment with adults however, we saw no such interference, and adults continued to benefit from phonological neighbours in recalling the pseudowords as they had done in explicit learning tasks.

However, differences in the experimental set-up make it challenging to interpret the differences between children and adults. First, adults were presented with the written stories to read along with the spoken stories, whereas children were not exposed to any orthography. This additional support enabled participants to revisit the novel words during the story, against the intended implicit nature of learning. Second, children sat separate 2-AFC recognition tasks to assess knowledge of the word-form and picture-form mapping independently, and the word-form recognition task was sensitive to neighbor effects. However, performance cannot be directly compared with adults because adults sat a combined 4-AFC version assessing form and picture knowledge simultaneously. Third, children provided spoken word responses, whereas adults provided typed responses. The present aim is to ameliorate these differences in a second adult study, using identical encoding and test formats to the original child experiment. 

Our primary research questions are as follows: 
1) Do adults show benefits from offline consolidation after learning novel words from spoken stories? 
2) Do adults show benefits of local prior knowledge (i.e., from word neighbours) when learning novel words from spoken stories?
3) Is the time course of local prior knowledge benefits different when adults learn novel words from spoken stories, compared to previous studies using explicit teaching paradigms (James et al., 2019)? 
4) Are benefits of local prior knowledge related to adults’ existing expressive vocabulary knowledge?
registration_responses.q4:
1) Memory for the novel words will be different after opportunities for consolidation at the day and week follow-up tests compared to when tested immediately after learning. In line with previous studies (James et al., 2019; Henderson et al., 2015), we predict that recall in the stem completion task will improve at later test points. 

2) Memory for the novel words will be affected by their number of phonological neighbours. For the stem completion task, we predict that words with one/more neighbours will be better recalled than words without neighbours. We also test this hypothesis in the recognition tasks, although do not predict a specific direction given our previous experiments have demonstrated that both interference and facilitation are plausible. 

3) The influence of word neighbours on memory for the novel words will change after opportunities for consolidation. If the same pattern holds as with explicit teaching paradigms, we would expect an early benefit of word neighbours to weaken after consolidation. However, if initial prior knowledge connections are weaker under storybook learning conditions, we may see that the influence of neighbours instead becomes strengthened with consolidation. This alternative would manifest as a delayed benefit for word neighbours at the day or week follow-up tests, and may be most prominent for words with only one neighbour due to their more limited prior knowledge connections. 

4) Expressive vocabulary scores will be positively associated with overall memory performance for the novel words. In line with previous findings, we anticipate that the association between vocabulary and memory performance will be strongest for novel words with only one phonological neighbour.

Where possible, interactions that do not enhance the fit of the model (p >.2) will be pruned to enable a more parsimonious model with better specified random effects. We will then adopt a forwards best path approach to building the random effects structure (Barr et al., 2013), incorporating only those random effects justified by the data under a liberal threshold (p <.2).
